https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 17/495
(a)The 2004 comprehensive plan of the village of Deerfield, including the following planning elements, all
of which shall comprise the comprehensive plan of the village of Deerfield:
(1) Existing land use map dated September 2004 (fig. 2.1).
(2) Future land use plan dated September 2004 (fig. 3.1).
(3) Annexation policy plan dated September 2004 (fig. 3.2).
(4) Transportation system plan dated September 2004 (fig. 3.6).
(5) Bicycle plan dated September 2004 (fig. 3.7).
(6) Parks and open space plan dated September 2004 (fig. 3.8).
(7) Community facilities plan dated September 2004 (fig. 3.9).
(8) Village center subarea plan.
(9) Lake Cook/Waukegan district subarea plan.
(10) Lake Cook Road corridor subarea plan.
(11) Deerfield Road corridor subarea plan.
(12) North Waukegan Road gateway subarea plan.
(13) Briarwood country club subarea plan.
(14) Hovland subarea plan.
(15) South of Lake Cook Road subarea plan.
(16) LaSalle and surrounding parcels subarea plan.
(b)The specifications for street construction and paving established by the president and board of
trustees.
(c)The zoning ordinance.
(d)The subdivision control ordinance. (Ord. 0-04-58, 10-4-2004)
Sec. 2-15. Elections For Municipal Offices:
Elections for municipal offices shall be held as provided by statute. (M.C. 1963, § 10.604)
Sec. 2-16. Impersonation Of Officer Or Employee Prohibited:
It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate without lawful authority any village officer or employee.
(M.C. 1963, § 10.112)
Article 2. Village President
Sec. 2-17. Election Of President; Term Of Office 4:
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 18/495
The village president shall be elected for a term of four (4) years, and he shall be the president of the
board of trustees, as provided by statute. (M.C. 1963, § 1.001)
Sec. 2-18. Powers And Duties Of The President 5:
(a)The president of the board of trustees shall be the chief executive officer of the village, and shall
perform all such duties as may be required of him by statute or this code or ordinance.
(b)He shall have supervision over all of the employees of the village.
(c)He shall have the power and authority to inspect all books and records kept by any village officer or
employee at any reasonable time. (M.C. 1963, § 1.002)
Sec. 2-19. Designation Of Duties By The President 10 :
(a) Whenever there is a question as to the respective powers or duties of any appointed officer of the
village, this shall be settled by the president.
(b) The president shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which is to be performed
when no specific officer has been directed to perform the duty. (M.C. 1963, § 1.003)
Sec. 2-20. President; Salary 11 :
The president shall receive such compensation as may be set, from time to time, by the board. (M.C.
1963, § 1.004)
Sec. 2-21. President Pro Tem 12 :
During the temporary absence or disability of the president, the board of trustees shall elect one of its
members to act as president pro tem, who during the absence or disability of the president shall preside
at board meetings, but shall vote as a trustee. (M.C. 1963, § 1.005)
Article 3. The Board Of Trustees 13
Division 1. General Provisions
Sec. 2-22. Election, Powers And Duties Of The Board Of Trustees:
(a) The board of trustees, consisting of six (6) members, shall be elected to office for a four (4) year
term, in the manner provided by statute.
(b) The board shall be the legislative department of the village government, and shall perform such
duties and have such powers as may be delegated by statute, or by this code or by ordinance. (M.C.
1963, § 2.101)
Sec. 2-23. Board Of Trustees; Oath; Salary 14 :
The members of the board of trustees shall receive such compensation as may be provided by
ordinance. (M.C. 1963, § 2.102)
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 19/495
Sec. 2-24. Regular And Special Meetings 15 :
(a) The board shall hold its regular meetings on the first and third Monday each month at seven thirty
o'clock (7:30) P.M., prevailing time, effective with the first regular board meeting in October 2001, and
no notice to the president and board of such regular meetings shall be required. (Ord. 0-01-33, 9-19-
2001)
(b) The meeting place of the board shall be at the village hall unless otherwise ordered by the village
board. Provided, however, that if the meeting date shall fall on a legal holiday, the board shall meet
on the day following.
(c) Special meetings may be called by the president or any three (3) trustees upon at least twenty four
(24) hours' notice, in writing, to all members and the president; provided, that if all the trustees are
present at a special meeting no notice of such meeting shall be necessary and such notice shall be
deemed waived.
(d) The village clerk shall have the duty of giving such notice to third persons of regular and special
meetings of the board as may be required by statute. (M.C. 1963, § 2.103)
Sec. 2-25. Quorum:
A majority of the trustees or three (3) trustees and the president shall constitute a quorum to do
business. (M.C. 1963, § 2.104)
Sec. 2-26. President As Presiding Officer:
The president shall be the presiding officer of all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees
and at all times when the board meets as a committee of the whole. In the absence of the president the
trustees present shall select one of their number to be president pro tem to preside at that meeting.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.105)
Sec. 2-27. Voting powers of President and President Pro Tem.
The President shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution or motion except he shall vote:
(1) Where the vote of the Trustees has resulted in a tie.
(2) Where one-half (1/2) of the Trustees have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion
even though there is no tie vote.
(3) Where required by statute nothing in this Section shall deprive a President Pro Tem from voting in
his capacity as Trustee but he shall not be entitled to another vote in his capacity as President Pro
Tem. (M.C. 1963, § 2.106)
Sec. 2-28. Ordinances; approval; veto.
(a) All resolutions and motions 1) which create any liability against the Village, or 2) which provide for the
expenditure or appropriation of its money, or 3) to sell any Village property, and all ordinances
passed by the affirmative vote of not less than four (4) Trustees or three (3) Trustees and the
President and shall be deposited with the Clerk.
(b) If the President approves of them, he shall sign them. Those of which he disapproves, he shall return
to the Board, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of the Board occurring not less
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 20/495
than five (5) days after their passage.
(c) The President may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution or
motion making any appropriation, and if so, the remainder shall be effective. However, the President
may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation.
(d) If the President fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution with his written objections
within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature. (M.C.
1963, § 2.107)
Sec. 2-29. Reconsideration; passing over veto.
(a) Every resolution and motion specified in Section 2-28 above, and every ordinance, which is returned
to the Board by the President shall be reconsidered by the Board.
(b) If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds (2/3) of all the Trustees elected to the Board shall agree to
pass an ordinance, resolution or motion, notwithstanding the President's refusal to approve it, then it
shall be effective.
(c) The vote on the question of passage over the President's veto shall be by yeas and nays and shall
be recorded in the journal. (M.C. 1963, § 2.108)
Sec. 2-30. Rescinded vote or action.
No vote or action of the Board shall be rescinded at any special meeting of the Board unless there be
present at such special meeting as many members of the Board as were present at the meeting when
such vote or action was taken, as provided by statute. (M.C. 1963, § 2.109)
Sec. 2-31. Addressing meetings of the Board.
No person other than the President or a member of the Board shall address that body at any regular or
special meeting except upon consent of a majority of the members present. (M.C. 1963, § 2.110)
Sec. 2-32. Disturbing meetings of the Board.
It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting of the Board or of any committee thereof. (M.C.
1963, § 2.111)
Sec. 2-33. Meetings of the Board open to the public.
All regular or special meetings of the Board shall be open to the public as provided by 5 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 120/1 et seq. (M.C. 1963, § 2.112)
Sec. 2-34. Vacancy in office of Trustee.
(a) Whenever a vacancy in the office of a Trustee occurs during his term, the vacancy shall be filled for
the remainder of the term at the next election of Trustees unless such vacancy is filled by a special
election as provided by statute.
(b) During the period from the time that the vacancy occurs until a Trustee is so elected and has
qualified, the vacancy may be filled by the appointment of a Trustee by the President and remaining
Trustees, voting jointly; provided, that no such action to fill a vacancy may be taken unless the
President and each of the remaining Trustees receives written notice that such action will be
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 21/495
proposed at the regular or special meeting to be held not less than fourteen (14) days following
receipt of said notice; provided, further, that the requirement of said notice may be waived with the
unanimous consent of the President and all of the remaining Trustees. (M.C. 1963, § 2.113; amd.
Ord. 0-72-35; Ord. 0-74-43)
Division 2. Meetings; Procedure: Rules of Order.
Sec. 2-35. Order of business.
(a) The first order of business shall be the approval of the minutes of the preceding meeting.
(b) All other matters shall be taken up in the order in which they appear on the agenda prepared by the
Manager; provided, that at the request of the President or any Trustee any topic on the agenda may,
with the consent of the Board, be considered at any time. (M.C. 1963, § 2.201)
Sec. 2-36. Precedence of motions.
(a) When a question is before the Board, no motion shall be entertained except:
(1) To adjourn;
(2) To fix the hour of adjournment;
(3) To lay on the table;
(4) For the previous question;
(5) To postpone indefinitely;
(6) To amend.
(b) Such motions shall have precedence in the order indicated.
(c) Any such motion, except a motion to amend, shall be put to a vote without debate. (M.C. 1963, §
2.203)
Sec. 2-37. Ordinances; introduction; passage.
(a) Ordinances shall not be passed until they have been presented on two (2) separate days at regular
or special meetings of the Board, unless the requirement of two (2) separate days be dispensed with
by affirmative votes of the majority of the members of the Board.
(b) At a subsequent meeting, or if a first reading has been waived, any Trustee may move the adoption
of that ordinance. If the motion receives a second, the chairman of the meeting shall direct the Clerk
to call the roll of the Trustees and record their oral vote, which vote may be taken without a full
reading of the ordinance, and the ordinances shall have been adopted by the affirmative vote of not
less than four (4) Trustees or three (3) Trustees and the President, unless a greater vote is required
by statute. (M.C. 1963, § 2.204)
Sec. 2-38. Motions to be stated; withdrawal of motion.
When a motion is made and seconded, it shall be stated before debate. A motion may not be withdrawn
by the mover without consent of the member seconding it.
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 22/495
(M.C. 1963, § 2.205.)
Sec. 2-39. Addressing meetings.
(a) Trustees desiring to speak shall address the chair and, upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall
confine himself to the question under debate and shall avoid all personalities.
(b) A Trustee once recognized, shall not be interrupted while speaking unless called to order by the
presiding officer, unless a point of order is raised by another member or unless the speaker chooses
to yield to questions from another member.
(c) Any member of the public permitted to address the Board shall be recognized by the chair, shall state
his name and address in an audible tone for the record, and shall limit his remarks to the question
under discussion.
All remarks and questions shall be addressed to the presiding officer and not to any individual member
thereof.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.206.)
Sec. 2-40. Enforcement of rules; appeal.
(a) The presiding officer shall preserve decorum and decide all questions of order, subject to appeal to
the Board.
(b) Any Trustee may appeal to the Board from a ruling of the presiding officer. If the appeal is seconded,
the member making the appeal may briefly state his reason for same, and the presiding officer may
briefly explain his ruling; but there shall be no debate on the appeal and no other member shall
participate in the discussion. The presiding officer shall then put the question, "Shall the decision of
the chair be sustained?" If a majority of the members vote "Aye", the ruling of the chair is sustained,
otherwise, it is overruled.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.207.)
Sec. 2-41. Limitation of debate.
(a) No member shall be allowed to speak more than once on any subject until every other member
choosing to speak thereon shall have spoken.
(b) No member shall speak more than twice upon any one subject, nor for a longer time than ten (10)
minutes, without leave of the Board.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.208.)
Sec. 2-42. Voting; request to be excused from voting.
(a) Every member present when a question is put shall vote either "aye" or "no", unless the Board shall,
for special reason, excuse him from voting.
(b) Request to be excused from voting must be made before the votes are called for; otherwise a passed
vote shall count with the majority voting.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.209.)
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 23/495
Sec. 2-43. Demand for roll call.
Upon demand of any member, the roll shall be called for yeas and nays upon any question before the
Board.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.210.)
Sec. 2-44. Motion to table.
A motion to lay on the table shall preclude all amendments or debate of the subject under consideration.
If the motion shall prevail, the consideration of the subject may be resumed only with the consent of a
majority of the members present.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.212.)
Sec. 2-45. Division of question.
If the question contains two (2) or more divisionable propositions, the presiding officer may, and upon
request of a member shall, divide the same.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.213.)
Sec. 2-46. Reconsideration.
After the decision on any question any member who voted with the majority or any member who was
absent at the time the action was taken may move a reconsideration of any action at the same or next
succeeding meeting, provided, however, that a resolution authorizing or relating to any contract may be
reconsidered at any time before the final execution thereof.
(M.C. 1963, § 2.214, Ord. No. 0-72-4.)
Sec. 2-47. Suspension of rules.
Any provisions of these rules may be temporarily suspended at any meeting of the Board, by the
affirmative vote of four (4) Trustees or three (3) Trustees and the President. (M.C. 1963, § 2.215)
Sec. 2-48. Procedure for the adoption of new or amended rules.
These rules may be amended or new rules adopted by a majority vote of all members of the Board. Any
such alterations or amendments shall be submitted, in writing, at the preceding regular meeting and
shall be placed on the agenda under order of new business. This requirement shall be waived only by
unanimous consent, with a recorded vote of all members. (M.C. 1963, § 2.216)
Sec. 2-49. Roberts' Rules of Order; when applicable.
For matters not covered by the foregoing rules of order, Roberts' Rules of Order shall be followed. (M.C.
1963, § 2.217)
Article 4. Village Clerk 16 .
Sec. 2-50. Appointment of Village Clerk; term.
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 24/495
The office of Village Clerk is hereby established. The office of Village Clerk shall be held by the Village
Manager who shall in addition to his other duties perform the duties of that office. (Ord. 0-89-14, 3-20-
89)
Sec. 2-51. General duties of the Village Clerk; compensation.
The Village Clerk shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by statute, by this Code or by
ordinance. (Ord. 0-89-14, 3-20-89)
Sec. 2-52. Vacancy.
In the event that the office of Village Clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the President and Board
of Trustees shall thereafter appoint a successor as provided herein. (Ord. 0-81-33, 4-20-81)
Sec. 2-53. Deputy Village Clerk(s).
The President and Board of Trustees may appoint, from time to time, one or more deputy village clerk(s)
who, in the absence or unavailability of the Village Clerk, shall perform all of the duties of that office.
(Ord. 0-81-33, 4-20-81)
Sec. 2-54 through 2-62 (Rep. by Ord. 0-81-33, 4-20-81).
Article 5. Village Manager.
Sec. 2-63. Office of Village Manger established.
The office of Village Manager is hereby established. (M.C. 1963, § 5.101)
Sec. 2-64. Appointment of Village Manger.
The Village Manager shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the
Board, for an indefinite term.He shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and administrative
qualifications with special reference to his actual experience in, or his knowledge of, accepted practice in
respect to the duties of his office hereinafter set forth. At the time of his appointment he need not be a
resident of the Village or the State, but during his tenure of office he shall reside within the Village. (M.C.
1963, § 5.102)
Sec. 2-65. Removal of Village Manager.
The Village Manager may be removed from office by a majority vote of the President and all Trustees
then holding office; provided, that no action to so remove the Village Manager shall be taken at a regular
or special meeting of the Board of Trustees unless ten (10) days prior thereto, written notice of such
proposed action shall be given to the President, each of the Trustees and the Village Manager; provided,
further that, prior to the taking of such action, the Village Manager may request of the President and/or
the Trustee(s) proposing such action, written charges or statement of the reasons for such proposed
action and shall be afforded the opportunity to be heard in response thereto. (M.C. 1963, § 5.103)
Sec. 2-66. Powers and duties of Village Manager.
(a) The Village Manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the Village. He shall be responsible to
the President and Board for the proper administration of the affairs of the Village. To that end, he
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 25/495
shall have power and shall be required to:
(1) Enforce all laws and ordinances of the Village.
(2) Attend all meetings of the Board. The Village Manager shall have the right to take part in the
discussion of all matters coming before the Board but shall have no right to vote. The Village
Manager shall be entitled to notice of all special and regular meetings of the Board.
(3) Recommend to the Board adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient.
(4) Devote his full time to the discharge of his official duties.
(5) Perform such other lawful duties as may be required by resolution or ordinance of the Board.
(6) Appoint, suspend or remove all employees of the Village. Such appointments, suspensions or
removals shall be based upon the merit and fitness of such employee, without regard to political
belief or affiliation and without regard to such employee's or prospective employee's race, color,
religion, sex, national origin or ancestry.
(7) Exercise control of all departments and divisions thereof now and in existence or that may
hereafter be.
(8) Make recommendations to the Board concerning compensation for each appointive office and
position in the Village service, including minimum, intermediate and maximum rates.
(9) Recommend to the Board the creating, consolidating and combining of offices, positions,
departments or units of the administrative and executive departments of the Village.
(10) Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the administration of the government
of the Village and services maintained by the public utilities in the Village and see that all franchises,
permits and privileges granted by the Village are faithfully observed.
(11) Purchase all materials, supplies and equipment in the manner provided in this Code.
(12) Keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the Village and the location of such
property. He shall be responsible for the care and custody of all Village property which is not by
statute, by this Code or ordinance assigned to some other officer or body for care and control.
(13) In the absence of a Director of Finance, the Village Manager shall perform all the duties of that
office. (M.C. 1963, § 5.104; amd. Ord. 0-72-11)
(14) The Village Manager shall perform all of the duties of the office of Village Clerk. (Ord. 0-89-14, 3-
20-89)
Sec. 2-67. Compensation of Village Manager.
The Village Manager shall receive such compensation as the Board shall fix, from time to time, by
ordinance. (M.C. 1963, § 5.106)
Sec. 2-68. Acting Village Manager.
During the temporary absence or disability of the Village Manager, the President shall appoint an Acting
Village Manager, with all the powers and duties of the office without furnishing any additional bond, if
such appointee shall already be under bond to the Village in any other capacity. (M.C. 1963, § 5.107)
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 26/495
Sec. 2-69. Vacancies.
In case of a vacancy in the office of Village Manager, the President with the consent of the Board shall
appoint a Manager Pro Tem who shall possess the powers and duties of the Manager until such time as
a new Village Manager is appointed. (M.C. 1963, § 5.108)
Article 6. Village Attorney and Village Prosecutor.
Sec. 2-70. Appointment of Village Attorney 17 .
The office of Village Attorney is hereby established. The Village Attorney shall be appointed by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board. (M.C. 1963, § 5.201)
Sec. 2-71. Powers and duties of Village Attorney.
(a) The Village Attorney shall:
(1) Prosecute or defend any and all actions to which the Village may be a party, or in which it may be
interested, or which may be brought against, or by, any officer of the Village on behalf of the Village,
or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the Village;
(2) Be the legal advisor of the Village, and render advice on all legal questions affecting the Village,
whenever requested to do so by any Village official;
(3) Upon request by the President of the Board, reduce his opinion to writing;
(4) Draft or supervise the phraseology of any contracts, leases or other documents or instruments to
which the Village may be a party;
(5) Draft ordinances and resolutions covering any subjects within the powers of the Village. (M.C.
1963, § 5.202, § 5.203, § 5.204)
Sec. 2-72. Village Prosecutor; appointment; powers and duties.
(a) The President, with the advice and consent of the Board, may appoint an attorney to prosecute
ordinance violation cases.
(b) It shall be the duty of the prosecutor to handle all such prosecutions in that branch of the Circuit
Court of Lake County and in that branch of the Circuit Court of Cook County assigned to hear and
determine cases involving a violation of a Village ordinance.
(c) The Village Attorney shall assist such Prosecutor upon request of the Prosecutor.
(d) The Prosecutor shall notify the Village Attorney of any notice of appeal served in connection with the
imposition of any fine or other penalty for a violation of a Village ordinance. (M.C. 1963, § 5.205;
amd. Ord. 0-64-35)
Article 7. Village Treasurer 18 .
Sec. 2-73. Appointment of Village Treasurer.
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 27/495
The office of Village Treasurer is hereby established. The Treasurer shall be appointed by the President
with advice and consent of the Board. (M.C. 1963, § 5.301)
Sec. 2-74. General duties of Village Treasurer 19 .
The Treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute, by this Code or
ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the Village whether directly from the person paying the
money or from the hands of such other officer or employee as may receive it, and he shall pay out
money only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the President and Clerk. (M.C. 1963, § 5.303)
Sec. 2-75. Deposit of funds by Village Treasurer.
(a) The Treasurer shall deposit the Village funds in such depositories as may be selected, from time to
time, as provided by law.
(b) The Treasurer shall keep the deposit of the Village money separate and distinct from his own money
and shall not make private or personal use of any Village money. (M.C. 1963, § 5.304)
Sec. 2-76. Records to be kept by Village Treasurer.
The Treasurer shall keep records showing all money received by him, showing the source from which it
is received and the purpose for which it is paid, and he shall keep records at all times showing the
financial status of the Village. (M.C. 1963, § 5.305)
Sec. 2-77. Accounting records to be kept by Village Treasurer.
The Treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by statute or by this Code or
ordinance and he shall keep them in the manner required by the Village Manager. (M.C. 1963, § 5.306)
Sec. 2-78. Warrants; requirements; compliance.
(a) All warrants drawn on Village funds must be signed by the President and countersigned by the Clerk,
stating the particular fund or appropriation to which the same is chargeable, and the person to whom
payable.
(b) No money shall be otherwise paid except as may be provided by statute or by this Code. (M.C. 1963,
§ 5.307)
Article 8. Administrative Departments and Officers 20 .
Division 1. Department of Finance.
Sec. 2-79. Establishment of Department of Finance.
There is hereby established the Department of Finance, an administrative department of the Village.
This Department shall consist of the Director of Finance and such other officers and employees as the
Board shall, from time to time, authorize. (M.C. 1963, § 6.101)
Sec. 2-80. Director of Finance.
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 28/495
(a) There is hereby established the position of Director of Finance, who shall be appointed by the Village
Manager.
(b) The Director of Finance shall have knowledge or experience in budgeting and financial control.
(c) The Director of Finance shall have control and supervision over all employees assigned to the
Department of Finance subject to the approval of the Village Manager. (M.C. 1963, § 6.102)
Sec. 2-81. Duties of Director of Finance.
The Director of Finance shall have charge of the administration of the financial affairs of the Village
subject to the control of the Village Manager and to that end he shall:
(1) Assist the Budget Officer in the preparation of the budget and tax levy ordinance;
(2) Conduct special studies and investigations into the financial affairs of the departments and offices
of the Village, at the direction of the Village Manager;
(3) Suggest standards and recommend to the Village Manger procedures to be employed in the
accounting for money and property by the Village department heads and officers;
(4) Supervise and be responsible for the disbursement of all monies and have control over all
expenditures to ensure that appropriations and budget provisions are not exceeded;
(5) Establish, organize and maintain a centralized accounting system to record completely all
financial transactions of the Village;
(6) Examine all contracts, purchase orders and other documents by which financial obligations are
incurred and every such document shall be subject to his certification as to the availability of funds
and the appropriation relating thereto;
(7) Be assistant purchasing agent, performing such duties relating to the office of purchasing agent
as are assigned by the Village Manager;
(8) Submit to the Board through the Village Manager a monthly statement of all receipts and
disbursements in sufficient detail to show the exact financial condition of the Village;
(9) Prepare for the Village Manager, as of the end of each fiscal year, a complete financial statement
and report;
(10) Collect and receive all money due on special assessments and special taxes that are not paid
directly to the Treasurer, and to keep such records pertaining to such collections as may be required
by statute, by this Code or ordinance. He shall make such reports regarding delinquent special
assessments as are required by statute of the Village Collector.
(11) Receive applications for and issue all licenses and permits required by this Code or ordinance in
the absence of any provisions to the contrary.
(12) Act as personnel officer for the Village. He shall maintain position classifications, pay plans and
personnel records for all Village employees reflecting tenure, qualifications, service, leaves of
absence and related matters.
(13) Perform such other functions as may be required by the Village Manager or by the President
and Board. (M.C. 1963, § 6.104)
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 29/495
Division 2. Budget Officer 21 .
Sec. 2-82. Appointment of Budget Officer; control and responsibility 22 .
(a) There is hereby established the administrative position of Budget Officer.
(b) The Budget Officer shall be appointed by the President, with the advice and consent of the Board, as
provided by statute.
(c) The Budget Office shall have knowledge or experience in budgeting and financial control and may
concurrently hold any other elected or appointed office in the Village and receive compensation for
both offices.
(d) The Budget Officer shall serve at the pleasure of the President.
(e) The Budget Officer shall have control and responsibility over preparation of an annual budget and all
other budgetary matters involving the Village and any Village departments, commissions or boards
subject to the control of the Village Manger. (M.C. 1963, § 6.101A; amd. Ord. 0-72-5)
Sec. 2-83. Duties of Budget Officer.
(a) The Budget Officer shall exercise the statutory powers and duties of his office provided in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.2, and pursuant to these duties, he shall:
(1) Permit and encourage and establish the use of efficient planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting,
accounting and other fiscal management procedures in all Village departments, commissions and
boards.
(2) Compile an annual budget in accordance with Section 2-84 of this Division.
(3) Examine all books and records of all Village departments, commissions and boards which relate
to monies received by the Village, its departments, commissions and boards, and paid out by the
Village, its departments, commissions and boards, debts and accounts receivable, amounts owed by
or to the Village, its departments, commissions and boards.
(4) Obtain such additional information from the Village, its departments, commissions and boards as
may be useful to the Budget Officer for purpose of compiling a municipal budget, such information to
be furnished by the Village, its departments, commissions and boards in the form required by the
Budget Officer. Any department, commission or board which refuses to make such information, as is
requested of it available to the Budget Officer, shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any
subsequent budget for the Village until such Village department, commission or board shall comply in
full with the request of the Budget Officer.
(5) Establish and maintain such procedures as shall insure that no expenditures are made by the
Village, its departments, commissions or boards except as authorized by the budget.
(6) Perform such other functions as may be required by the Village Manager or by the President and
the Board.
(M.C. 1963, § 6.103A; Ord. No. 0-72-5.)
Sec. 2-84. Annual budget requirements; compilation and contents.
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 30/495
(a) The Budget Officer shall compile a budget, such budget to contain estimates of revenues available to
the Village for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended
expenditures for the Village and all of its departments, commissions and boards.
(b) Revenue estimates and expenditure recommendations shall be presented in a manner which is in
conformity with good fiscal management practices. Substantial conformity to a chart of accounts, now
or in the future recommended by the National Committee on Governmental Accounting or the Auditor
of Public Accounts of the State of Illinois, or the Division of Local Governmental Affairs and Property
Taxes of the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois or successor agencies shall be deemed
proof of such conformity.
(c) The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the two (2) years
immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. So far as is possible, the
fiscal data for such two (2) preceding fiscal years shall be itemized in a manner which is in conformity
with the chart of accounts approved above.
(d) Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made.
(M.C. 1963, § 6.104A; Ord. No. 0-72-5.)
Sec. 2-85. Capital improvements, repair and replacement fund.
(a) In the preparation by the Budget Officer of the annual budget, one-half (1/2) of one (1) percentum of
equalized assessed value of property subject to taxation by the Village may be accumulated in a
separate fund for the purpose or purposes of specific capital improvements, repairs and/or
replacements of specific types of Village equipment or other tangible property, both real and
personal, to be designated as the `Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund.'
(b) Expenditures from the Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund shall be budgeted in the
fiscal year in which the capital improvement, repair or replacement will occur.
(c) Upon the completion or abandonment of any object for which the Capital Improvement, Repair or
Replacement Fund, or should any surplus monies remain after the completion or abandonment of
any object for which the Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund was inaugurated, then
such funds no longer necessary for capital improvement, repair or replacement shall be transferred
into the general corporate fund of the Village on the first day of the fiscal year following such
abandonment, completion or discovery of surplus funds.
(M.C. 1963, § 6.105A; Ord. No. 0-72-5.)
Sec. 2-86. Contingency funds.
The annual budget may contain money set aside for contingency purposes not to exceed ten (10)
percent of the total budget, less the amount set aside for contingency purposes, which monies may be
expended for contingencies upon a majority vote of the President and the Board then holding office.
(M.C. 1963, § 6.106A; Ord. No. 0-72-5.)
Sec. 2-87. Revision of annual budget.
With the prior approval of the Budget Officer, the head of any Village department, commission or board
may delete, add to, change or create sub-classes within object classes budgeted previously to the
department, commission or board. By a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the Trustees then holding office, the
annual budget for the Village may be revised by deleting, adding to, changing or creating sub-classes
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 31/495
within object classes and object classes themselves. No revision of the budget shall be made increasing
the budget in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the revision.
(M.C. 1963, § 6.107A; Ord. No. 0-72-5.)
Sec. 2-88. Adoption of annual budget.
Passage of the annual budget by the President and Board of Trustees shall be in lieu of passage of the
appropriation ordinances as required by statute. The annual budget need not be published except in a
manner provided for in Section 2-89. The annual budget shall be adopted by the President and the
Board before the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies.
(M.C. 1963, § 6.108A; Ord. No. 0-72-5.)
Sec. 2-89. Public inspection, notice and hearing on annual budget.
(a)The president and the board shall make the tentative annual budget conveniently available to public
inspection for at least ten (10) days prior to the passage of the annual budget, by publication in the
journal of the proceedings of the president and the board or in such other form as the president and
the board prescribe.
(b)Not less than one week after the publication of the tentative annual budget and prior to final action on
the budget, the president and the board shall hold at least one public hearing on the tentative annual
budget after which hearing or hearings the tentative budget may be further revised and passed
without any further inspection, notice or hearing. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication
in a newspaper having a general circulation in the village at least one week prior to the time of the
hearing. (M.C. 1963, § 6.109A; amd. Ord. 0-72-5)
Division 3. Department Of Community Development
Sec. 2-90. Establishment Of Department Of Community Development:
There is hereby established the department of community development, an administrative department of
the village. This department shall consist of the director of community development and such other
employees as the board shall, from time to time, authorize. (Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
Sec. 2-91. Director Of Community Development; Appointment; Control And
Supervision:
There is hereby established the position of director of community development who shall be appointed
by the village manager. The director of community development shall have control and supervision over
all employees assigned to the department of community development, subject to the approval of the
village manager, and be responsible for all matters related to land use planning, zoning and building
code enforcement. (Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
Sec. 2-92. Powers And Duties Of Director Of Community Development:
(a)The director of community development shall:
(1) Enforce, or cause to be enforced, all laws and ordinances relating to the construction, repair or
alteration of buildings and structures and the use of streets or parkways in connection therewith, and
make, or cause to be made, all inspections needed for that purpose;
6/5/2019 Code Book Viewer
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/IL/Deerfield/index.htm 32/495
(2) Issue, or cause to be issued, all proper permits for such work after payment of the fees required
to the director of finance;
(3) Enforce or cause to be enforced all village ordinances relating to the installation, care and
standards of plumbing, electric signs, electrical wiring and electrically operated equipment;
(4) Perform or cause to be performed all duties assigned by this code, or by any other ordinances or
laws relating to his office;
(5) Be the zoning enforcement officer of the village and see to the enforcement of the zoning
ordinance;
(6) Enforce or cause to be enforced the provisions of the property maintenance code as adopted by
the village from time to time pursuant to section 13-1 of this code and in the course of said
enforcement issue or cause to be issued any such citations or orders resulting from violations of said
code and initiate prosecution of any such violations with the cooperation of the village prosecutor of
the village. (Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
Sec. 2-93. Stop Order Requirements:
(a)The director of community development or his designee shall have the power to order all work
stopped on construction, alteration or repair of any building when the work is being done in violation
of any provision of this code or any ordinance relating thereto, or in violation of the zoning ordinance.
(b)Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the written permission of the
director of community development, provided, that if the stop order is an oral one, it shall be followed
by written stop order within an hour. Such written stop order may be served by any police officer.
(Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
Sec. 2-94. Entry Powers Of Director Of Community Development:
The director of community development or his designee shall have the power to make or cause to be
made entry into any building or premises where the work of altering, repairing or constructing any
building or structure is being conducted, for the purpose of making inspections at any reasonable hour.
(Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
Sec. 2-95. Reports To Lake And Cook County:
Within fifteen (15) days after the issuance of a building permit, the director of community development or
his designee shall send a copy of the permit, together with a complete legal description of the area to
which the permit pertains, and the real estate index number, if any, to the county assessor and township
assessor in which county and township said area is situated. (Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
Division 4. Department Of Public Works And Engineering
Sec. 2-96. Establishment Of Department Of Public Works And Engineering:
There is hereby established a department of public works and engineering, an administrative department
of the village. This department shall consist of the director of public works and engineering and such
other employees as the board shall, from time to time, authorize. (Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)

Sec. 2-97. Appointment Of Director Of Public Works And Engineering; Control And
Supervision:
There is hereby established the position of director of public works and engineering who shall be the
head of the department. The director shall be appointed for an indefinite term by the village manager
and shall have control and supervision over all employees assigned to the department subject to
approval of the village manager. (Ord. 0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
Sec. 2-98. Powers And Duties Of Director Of Public Works And Engineering:
(a)The director of public works and engineering shall:
(1) Have charge and supervision over all public property of the village, including all streets, parks,
parkways, sidewalks, municipal buildings and all other property of the village not specifically

(2) Have charge of, and be responsible for, the care, maintenance and operation of the water system,
the sanitary sewer system and disposal plant, the street lighting system, all streets and sidewalks
and the drainage thereof;
(3) Have charge of and be responsible for the condition of all motor vehicles; trucks and other public

(4) Conduct all required inspections of village improvements constructed or installed by contractors;
(5) Perform all duties assigned by this code or by other ordinances or laws relating to this office;
(6) Have the power to order all work stopped on the construction, alteration or repair of any municipal
improvement when the work is being done in violation of any provision of this code or any ordinances
relating thereto. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the written
permission of the village manager, providing that if the stop order is an oral one, it shall be followed
by a written stop order within one hour. Such written stop may be served by any police officer. (Ord.
0-88-42, 7-18-1988)
